etymology.description: semantic: 肉 (“flesh”) + pictograph of stomach/food (later simplified to 田, referencing rice 米).
etymology.interpretation: Combines the body-part indicator 肉 with an early pictograph of a stomach filled with food. The later 田 shape preserves the idea of grains/food (rice) inside the organ, pointing to the stomach’s function.

examples.chinese: 我胃疼，需要去看医生(我胃疼，需要去看醫生)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ wèi téng, xūyào qù kàn yīshēng.
examples.english: My stomach hurts; I need to see a doctor.

examples.chinese: 她的胃口很好，什么都能吃(她的胃口很好，什麼都能吃)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de wèikǒu hěn hǎo, shénme dōu néng chī.
examples.english: She has a good appetite and can eat anything.

examples.chinese: 饭后别立刻跑步，以免伤胃(飯後別立刻跑步，以免傷胃)。
examples.pinyin: Fàn hòu bié lìkè pǎobù, yǐmiǎn shāng wèi.
examples.english: Don’t run immediately after meals to avoid hurting the stomach.
